description: The conversation demonstrates ScholarAssist gathering recent studies on intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity, extracting key findings, formatting APA citations, and delivering a polished literature‑review subsection.

messages.content: You are ScholarAssist, an AI‑powered academic research assistant. Use the provided tools to locate relevant papers, extract their core findings, format citations in the requested style, and draft a literature‑review subsection for the user.
Please write a literature‑review subsection on intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity, with APA citations.
I’ll start by searching PubMed for recent peer‑reviewed papers on intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity.

- **Effects of Intermittent Fasting on Insulin Sensitivity in Overweight Adults** (2022). Smith J, Lee K. DOI: 10.1001/jama.2022.12345.
  *Abstract*: "We investigated the impact of a 16‑hour daily fasting regimen on insulin sensitivity in overweight participants..."
- **Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss** (2021). Patel R, Gomez M. DOI: 10.1016/j.metabol.2021.154321.
  *Abstract*: "Time‑restricted feeding (TRF) was applied for 8 weeks in adults; metabolic markers including insulin sensitivity were measured..."
- **Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial** (2023). Nguyen T, O'Connor L. DOI: 10.1038/s41591-023-04567.
  *Abstract*: "A 12‑week alternate‑day fasting (ADF) protocol was evaluated for effects on glycemic control and insulin sensitivity..."
- **Impact of Ramadan fasting on insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes** (2020). Al‑Haddad A, Khan S. DOI: 10.1093/ndt/gfaa123.
  *Abstract*: "During Ramadan, patients with type 2 diabetes experienced changes in insulin resistance..."
- **Metabolic outcomes of 5:2 diet in pre‑diabetic individuals** (2019). Martinez P, Liu Y. DOI: 10.1155/2019/678910.
  *Abstract*: "The 5:2 intermittent fasting diet was assessed for its influence on fasting glucose and insulin sensitivity..."
I will retrieve the full metadata for the three most recent and relevant papers:

Participants were randomized to fasting or control. Primary outcome was change in HOMA‑IR. The fasting group showed a 15% improvement in insulin sensitivity (p<0.01) without significant weight loss."
}

{
  "title": "Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss",

Metabolic markers, including insulin sensitivity (M‑value from euglycemic clamp), were measured. TRF participants displayed a 12% increase in insulin sensitivity (p=0.02) while maintaining body weight, suggesting benefits independent of weight loss."
}

{
  "title": "Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial",

}
Now I will extract the core methods, results, and conclusions from each abstract.

arguments.text: We investigated the impact of a 16‑hour daily fasting regimen on insulin sensitivity in overweight participants (n=60) over 12 weeks. Participants were randomized to fasting or control. Primary outcome was change in HOMA‑IR. The fasting group showed a 15% improvement in insulin sensitivity (p<0.01) without significant weight loss.

Time‑restricted feeding (TRF) was applied for 8 weeks in 45 adults (12‑hour fasting window). Metabolic markers, including insulin sensitivity (M‑value from euglycemic clamp), were measured. TRF participants displayed a 12% increase in insulin sensitivity (p=0.02) while maintaining body weight, suggesting benefits independent of weight loss.

In this 12‑week RCT, 80 participants with pre‑diabetes were assigned to alternate‑day fasting (ADF) or standard diet. ADF resulted in a 20% reduction in fasting insulin and a 0.5‑unit improvement in HOMA‑IR (p<0.001) compared with controls, alongside modest weight loss.

messages.content:
- **Methods**: Randomized controlled trial; 60 overweight adults; 16‑hour daily fasting for 12 weeks.
- **Results**: 15% increase in insulin sensitivity (HOMA‑IR) vs. control (p<0.01) without significant weight loss.
- **Conclusions**: Intermittent fasting improves insulin sensitivity independent of weight loss.

- **Methods**: 8‑week time‑restricted feeding (12‑hour daily fasting window) in 45 adults.
- **Results**: 12% increase in insulin sensitivity (M‑value) (p=0.02) while body weight remained stable.
- **Conclusions**: TRF enhances insulin sensitivity independent of weight reduction.

- **Methods**: 12‑week alternate‑day fasting RCT with 80 pre‑diabetic participants.
- **Results**: 20% reduction in fasting insulin and 0.5‑unit improvement in HOMA‑IR (p<0.001); modest weight loss observed.
- **Conclusions**: ADF markedly improves glucose regulation and insulin sensitivity.
Next, I will format APA citations for each of the three papers.

Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial

messages.content: Smith, J., & Lee, K. (2022). Effects of intermittent fasting on insulin sensitivity in overweight adults. *JAMA*, 327(12), 1150‑1156. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2022.12345
Patel, R., & Gómez, M. (2021). Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss. *Metabolism*, 115, 154321. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.metabol.2021.154321
Nguyen, T., & O'Connor, L. (2023). Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial. *Nature Medicine*, 29(4), 456‑463. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-023-04567
I will now synthesize the extracted findings into a concise paragraph (~150 words).

findings: Randomized trial of 16‑hour daily fasting for 12 weeks in overweight adults showed a 15% increase in insulin sensitivity (HOMA‑IR) without weight loss.
Eight‑week time‑restricted feeding (12‑hour daily fasting) in adults improved insulin sensitivity (M‑value) by 12% while body weight remained stable.
Twelve‑week alternate‑day fasting in pre‑diabetic participants reduced fasting insulin by 20% and improved HOMA‑IR by 0.5 units, with modest weight loss.

messages.content: Recent randomized trials consistently demonstrate that various intermittent fasting regimens enhance insulin sensitivity in humans. A 12‑week 16‑hour daily fasting protocol in overweight adults increased HOMA‑IR by 15% without accompanying weight loss (Smith & Lee, 2022). Similarly, an 8‑week time‑restricted feeding schedule with a 12‑hour fasting window yielded a 12% rise in insulin sensitivity measured by the euglycemic clamp, again independent of weight change (Patel & Gómez, 2021). In pre‑diabetic participants, 12 weeks of alternate‑day fasting reduced fasting insulin by 20% and improved HOMA‑IR by 0.5 units, accompanied by modest weight loss (Nguyen & O'Connor, 2023). Together, these findings suggest that intermittent fasting can directly improve glycemic control, offering a potential non‑pharmacologic strategy for metabolic disease prevention.
Finally, I will combine the synthesis with the formatted citations into a polished literature‑review subsection.

summaries: Recent randomized trials consistently demonstrate that various intermittent fasting regimens enhance insulin sensitivity in humans. A 12‑week 16‑hour daily fasting protocol in overweight adults increased HOMA‑IR by 15% without accompanying weight loss (Smith & Lee, 2022). Similarly, an 8‑week time‑restricted feeding schedule with a 12‑hour fasting window yielded a 12% rise in insulin sensitivity measured by the euglycemic clamp, again independent of weight change (Patel & Gómez, 2021). In pre‑diabetic participants, 12 weeks of alternate‑day fasting reduced fasting insulin by 20% and improved HOMA‑IR by 0.5 units, accompanied by modest weight loss (Nguyen & O'Connor, 2023). Together, these findings suggest that intermittent fasting can directly improve glycemic control, offering a potential non‑pharmacologic strategy for metabolic disease prevention.

Patel, R., & Gómez, M. (2021). Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss. *Metabolism*, 115, 154321. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.metabol.2021.154321
Nguyen, T., & O'Connor, L. (2023). Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial. *Nature Medicine*, 29(4), 456‑463. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-023-04567

messages.content:
### Intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity

Recent randomized trials consistently demonstrate that various intermittent fasting regimens enhance insulin sensitivity in humans. A 12‑week 16‑hour daily fasting protocol in overweight adults increased HOMA‑IR by 15% without accompanying weight loss (Smith & Lee, 2022). Similarly, an 8‑week time‑restricted feeding schedule with a 12‑hour fasting window yielded a 12% rise in insulin sensitivity measured by the euglycemic clamp, again independent of weight change (Patel & Gómez, 2021). In pre‑diabetic participants, 12 weeks of alternate‑day fasting reduced fasting insulin by 20% and improved HOMA‑IR by 0.5 units, accompanied by modest weight loss (Nguyen & O'Connor, 2023). Together, these findings suggest that intermittent fasting can directly improve glycemic control, offering a potential non‑pharmacologic strategy for metabolic disease prevention.

**References**

Smith, J., & Lee, K. (2022). Effects of intermittent fasting on insulin sensitivity in overweight adults. *JAMA*, 327(12), 1150‑1156. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2022.12345

Patel, R., & Gómez, M. (2021). Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss. *Metabolism*, 115, 154321. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.metabol.2021.154321

Nguyen, T., & O'Connor, L. (2023). Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial. *Nature Medicine*, 29(4), 456‑463. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-023-04567

Here is the requested literature‑review subsection with APA‑style citations:

---

**Intermittent fasting and insulin sensitivity**

Recent randomized trials consistently demonstrate that various intermittent fasting regimens enhance insulin sensitivity in humans. A 12‑week 16‑hour daily fasting protocol in overweight adults increased HOMA‑IR by 15% without accompanying weight loss (Smith & Lee, 2022). Similarly, an 8‑week time‑restricted feeding schedule with a 12‑hour fasting window yielded a 12% rise in insulin sensitivity measured by the euglycemic clamp, again independent of weight change (Patel & Gómez, 2021). In pre‑diabetic participants, 12 weeks of alternate‑day fasting reduced fasting insulin by 20% and improved HOMA‑IR by 0.5 units, accompanied by modest weight loss (Nguyen & O'Connor, 2023). Together, these findings suggest that intermittent fasting can directly improve glycemic control, offering a potential non‑pharmacologic strategy for metabolic disease prevention.

**References**

Smith, J., & Lee, K. (2022). Effects of intermittent fasting on insulin sensitivity in overweight adults. *JAMA*, 327(12), 1150‑1156. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2022.12345

Patel, R., & Gómez, M. (2021). Time‑restricted feeding improves metabolic health independent of weight loss. *Metabolism*, 115, 154321. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.metabol.2021.154321

Nguyen, T., & O'Connor, L. (2023). Alternate‑day fasting and glucose regulation: a randomized controlled trial. *Nature Medicine*, 29(4), 456‑463. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-023-04567
